wikipedia_page.main: William Ritchie (1817–1862) was an English barrister, Advocate-General of Bengal from 1855 to 1862.

response: He was born in Calcutta, British India, the third son of the jurist William Ritchie (1817–1862) and his wife, Augusta Charlotte Trimmer.India, Select Births and Baptisms, 1786-1947 He was educated at Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge.

Freshfield married Augusta Charlotte Ritchie (1847–1911) on 27 November 1869. She was the daughter of William Ritchie and the sister of Sir Richmond Ritchie. They had four daughters and a son, Henry Douglas Freshfield, who died aged fourteen in 1891. The family loss was the occasion of a memorial gift for the people of Forest Row in the form of a building to be used as a parochial hall and institute.
* William Ritchie (editor) (1781–1831), editor of The Scotsman
* William Ritchie (moderator) (1758–1830), Moderator of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland

He was the eldest son of George Woodfield Paul, Vicar of Finedon, and Jessie Philippa Mackworth.Who Was Who, 1929-40 He was educated at Eton College and Corpus Christi College, Oxford, where he became President of the Oxford Union. He was called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn in 1878. He was a leader-writer on the Daily News. In 1883 he married Elinor Budworth, daughter of the Hon. William Ritchie, Legal member of the Viceregal Council at Calcutta.Foster, Men at the Bar, 1885

Blanche was born in Calcutta, India. Her father was William Ritchie, Advocate-General of Bengal, and her brother Sir Richmond Ritchie, who spent most of his working life in the Indian Office. In 1866, aged 18, she married Francis Warre-Cornish, a master at Eton College and ultimately Vice-Provost of the school. Their several children included the writer Mary MacCarthy and Cecilia Fisher, who married William Wordsworth Fisher, later an admiral. Blanche Warre-Cornish died in Kensington, London.
*William Ritchie 1855–1861 Bengal: Past and Present, Volume 64

link_mentions.page: List of vice-chancellors of the University of Calcutta

response: Erskine was born in 1821 in Bombay Presidency. He studied in University of Edinburgh, joined in Indian Civil Service and served as Judge of the Bombay High Court since 1862 to 1865. After William Ritchie he was appointed as the vice-chancellors of the Calcutta University on 8 April 1862. Erskine retired from the Civil service on 14 May 1867.
